sgcool_label_text:This batik is structured in the pagi-sore format
 comprising two different but related designs on each half of the kain panjang.  On one side
 lily of the Nile blooms are set against diagonal bands
 and surrounded with pairs of birds and lanterns bearing the Chinese character ‘double happiness’
 possibly symbolising marital bliss and congeniality.  The other half of this kain panjang is decorated with pairs of swans
 birds in flight and flowers set against vertical bands of background patterning.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987)
 the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures
 she used her husband’s name
 Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards
 she used Jane Hendromartono
 combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name
 Hendromartono with Jane
 as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother
 and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds
 rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe
 America and Japan
 especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Batik Kesenian Liem Siok Hien Kudus”.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: This batik is structured in the pagi-sore format, comprising two different but related designs on each half of the kain panjang.  On one side, lily of the Nile blooms are set against diagonal bands, and surrounded with pairs of birds and lanterns bearing the Chinese character ‘double happiness’, possibly symbolising marital bliss and congeniality.  The other half of this kain panjang is decorated with pairs of swans, birds in flight and flowers set against vertical bands of background patterning.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Batik Kesenian Liem Siok Hien Kudus”.
